text: The core of product management is competency-based, meaning there is someone in an organization that represents the customer the best, that has a deep knowledge of the customers and your users, that has a deep knowledge of your data, your industry, your business and the product itself.
speaker: Christian Idiodi
context: Lenny discusses the common dislike for product managers and asks Christian why this is often the case. Christian explains that many people dislike product managers because they have not experienced effective ones. He highlights that the role of a product manager should be competency-based, where they possess deep knowledge about customers, data, and the product, allowing them to make informed decisions that benefit the organization.
text_ko: 제품 관리의 핵심은 역량 기반이에요. 즉, 고객을 가장 잘 대변하는 사람이 조직 내에 있어야 하고, 고객과 사용자에 대한 깊은 이해가 필요해요. 그리고 데이터, 산업, 비즈니스, 제품 자체에 대해서도 잘 알아야 해요.
text_zh: 产品管理的核心是基于能力的，这意味着在一个组织中，有人能够最好地代表客户，具备对客户和用户的深刻理解，同时对数据、行业、业务和产品本身也有深入的了解。
text_es: El núcleo de la gestión de productos se basa en competencias, lo que significa que hay alguien en la organización que representa mejor al cliente, que tiene un profundo conocimiento de los clientes y los usuarios, así como un amplio entendimiento de tus datos, tu industria, tu negocio y el producto en sí.
key_sentence: Product management is competency-based, representing the customer with deep knowledge.

text: I often say to him, I say, 'Well, Bob said put up manager.' And it's often interesting to executives when I try to explain that way. I say that's the competent level that we're talking about here.
speaker: Christian Idiodi
context: In response to Lenny's question about the dislike for product managers, Christian illustrates how executives often trust long-serving employees over product managers due to their perceived competence. He uses the example of a hypothetical Bob, who has been with the company for a long time and is trusted to make decisions, to emphasize that product managers must demonstrate their competency to be respected and trusted in their decision-making.
text_ko: 저는 그에게 자주 이렇게 말해요, '음, 밥이 매니저를 세우라고 했어.' 이렇게 설명하면 경영진들이 흥미롭게 생각하는 경우가 많아요. 제가 말하는 건 우리가 이야기하는 유능한 수준이라는 거예요.
text_zh: 我常对他说：“好吧，鲍勃说要提升经理。”我发现这样解释对高管们来说通常很有趣。我说，这就是我们所谈论的能力水平。
text_es: A menudo le digo, 'Bueno, Bob dijo que se debe poner al gerente.' Y suele ser interesante para los ejecutivos cuando trato de explicarlo de esa manera. Digo que ese es el nivel de competencia (competent level) del que estamos hablando aquí.
key_sentence: That's the competent level we're discussing here.

text: There is this period of humility that I challenge all product managers to have, this period of learning, recognizing what you do not know.
speaker: Christian Idiodi
context: Lenny asks Christian how product managers can become more effective and less disliked. Christian stresses the importance of humility and a willingness to learn for product managers. He suggests that they should recognize their limitations and actively seek mentorship and knowledge from experienced colleagues to build their competence and trust within the organization.
text_ko: 모든 제품 관리자에게 도전하고 싶은 겸손의 시기가 있어요. 배우고, 내가 모르는 것을 인식하는 그런 시기요.
text_zh: 我鼓励所有产品经理经历一个谦逊的阶段，这是一个学习的过程，认识到自己所不知道的事情。
text_es: Hay un período de humildad que desafío a todos los gerentes de producto a tener, un período de aprendizaje, reconociendo lo que no saben.
key_sentence: Embrace a period of humility, recognizing what you do not know.

text: I always practically advise product managers in this kind of scenario, build relationships with people. You earn their trust by asking them to do two things. One, you're either going to teach me or I'm going to help you.
speaker: Christian Idiodi
context: Christian shares practical advice for product managers to build trust and rapport within their teams. He emphasizes the importance of relationship-building by either asking colleagues to teach them or offering to help them. This collaborative approach fosters trust and helps product managers learn from those around them, enhancing their effectiveness in their roles.
text_ko: 이런 상황에서는 제품 관리자들에게 항상 이렇게 조언해요. 사람들과 관계를 잘 쌓아야 해요. 신뢰를 얻으려면 두 가지를 요청하면 돼요. 하나는, 당신이 나에게 가르쳐주거나, 아니면 내가 당신을 도와줄게요.
text_zh: 在这种情况下，我总是建议产品经理建立人际关系。通过让他们做两件事来赢得他们的信任。第一，你要么教我，要么我来帮助你。
text_es: Siempre aconsejo a los gerentes de producto en este tipo de situaciones que construyan relaciones con las personas. Ganas su confianza pidiéndoles que hagan dos cosas. Primero, o me vas a enseñar o yo te voy a ayudar.
key_sentence: Build relationships to earn trust through collaboration.

text: The holy grail of product work is really a reference customer. This is somebody that has used your solution or your product, loves it enough to tell people about it.
speaker: Christian Idiodi
context: Lenny asks Christian about the most effective method for discovering what to build in product management. Christian highlights the importance of reference customers—those who not only use the product but also advocate for it to others. He underscores that reference customers are critical because their endorsement can significantly influence future customers and validate the product's value.
text_ko: 제품 작업의 성배는 사실상 레퍼런스 고객이에요. 이 고객은 당신의 솔루션이나 제품을 사용해보고, 그걸 정말 좋아해서 다른 사람들에게 추천해주는 사람이죠.
text_zh: 产品工作的圣杯实际上是一个参考客户。这是一个已经使用过你的解决方案或产品，并且非常喜欢，以至于愿意向他人推荐的人。
text_es: El santo grial del trabajo de producto es, en realidad, un cliente de referencia. Esta es una persona que ha utilizado tu solución o tu producto y lo ama lo suficiente como para recomendarlo a otros.
key_sentence: The holy grail of product work is a reference customer advocate.

text: You will get all the answers, the research, the failure, the mistakes, all the evidence. You know the difference between what people say, this is what they do.
speaker: Christian Idiodi
context: In discussing the discovery process in product management, Christian emphasizes the importance of hands-on problem-solving over traditional research methods. He argues that direct engagement with customers will yield real insights and evidence about their needs, contrasting this with the often unreliable nature of what customers verbally express they want.
text_ko: 모든 답변과 연구, 실패, 실수, 그리고 모든 증거를 얻게 될 거예요. 사람들이 하는 말과 실제 행동의 차이를 아는 게 중요해요.
text_zh: 你将获得所有的答案、研究、失败、错误和所有证据。你知道人们所说的与他们实际所做的之间的区别。
text_es: Obtendrás todas las respuestas, la investigación, los fracasos, los errores, toda la evidencia. Sabes la diferencia entre lo que la gente dice y lo que realmente hace.
key_sentence: Hands-on problem-solving reveals the difference between what people say and do.
